PART 2 — CODING YOUR MODULE (SIMPLE VERSION)

Paste this basic structure first:

Python
import cv2
import numpy as np

class SkinTypeAnalyzer:
    def analyze(self, face_roi):

        # Convert to HSV
        hsv = cv2.cvtColor(face_roi, cv2.COLOR_BGR2HSV)
        h, s, v = cv2.split(hsv)

        mean_s = np.mean(s)
        mean_v = np.mean(v)

        # Convert to grayscale for texture
        gray = cv2.cvtColor(face_roi, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)
        laplacian_var = cv2.Laplacian(gray, cv2.CV_64F).var()

        # Basic rule-based logic
        if mean_s > 110 and mean_v > 150:
            skin_type = "oily"
        elif mean_s < 60 and mean_v < 120:
            skin_type = "dry"
        elif laplacian_var > 500:
            skin_type = "acne_prone"
        else:
            skin_type = "normal"

        return {
            "skin_type": skin_type,
            "mean_s": float(mean_s),
            "mean_v": float(mean_v),
            "texture_score": float(laplacian_var)
        }

Don’t worry about perfection.
We improve later.

✅ Step 1 — Paste This Starter Code

Inside skintype_analyzer.py, paste this:

Python
import cv2
import numpy as np


def analyze_skin_type(image):
    """
    Basic heuristic skin type detection.
    image: numpy array (BGR image from OpenCV)
    returns: string (skin type)
    """

    # Convert to grayscale
    gray = cv2.cvtColor(image, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)

    # Calculate brightness mean
    brightness = np.mean(gray)

    # Calculate standard deviation (texture roughness)
    texture_variation = np.std(gray)

    # Simple heuristic rules (Phase 1 logic)
    if brightness > 170 and texture_variation < 30:
        return "dry"
    elif brightness < 100 and texture_variation > 50:
        return "oily"
    elif texture_variation > 70:
        return "acne_prone"
    elif 100 <= brightness <= 170:
        return "normal"
    else:
        return "combination"

🧠 What This Does

It:

  • Takes image

  • Converts to grayscale

  • Measures brightness

  • Measures texture variation

  • Returns simple classification

This is PERFECT for Phase 1.

You don’t need CNN right now.

✅ CLEANED & PROPER VERSION

Replace your file with this refined version:

Python
import cv2
import numpy as np


class SkinTypeAnalyzer:

    def analyze(self, image):
        """
        Analyze skin type using HSV + texture heuristics.
        image: BGR OpenCV image
        return: skin_type (string)
        """

        # Convert to HSV
        hsv = cv2.cvtColor(image, cv2.COLOR_BGR2HSV)
        h, s, v = cv2.split(hsv)

        mean_s = np.mean(s)
        mean_v = np.mean(v)

        # Texture analysis (roughness detection)
        gray = cv2.cvtColor(image, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)
        texture = cv2.Laplacian(gray, cv2.CV_64F).var()

        # Heuristic logic
        if mean_s > 120 and mean_v > 140:
            skin_type = "oily"

        elif mean_s < 60 and mean_v < 120:
            skin_type = "dry"

        elif texture > 150:
            skin_type = "acne_prone"

        elif 60 <= mean_s <= 120:
            skin_type = "normal"

        else:
            skin_type = "combination"

        return skin_type

🧠 Why This Is Better

✔ Uses HSV (good for skin analysis)
✔ Uses saturation for oil detection
✔ Uses brightness for dryness
✔ Uses Laplacian variance for acne detection
✔ Always returns value

This is PRESENTABLE to faculty.

ChatGPT said:

Good. You were very close.

The only mistake is:

You detected face_region…

We must run analysis on face_region, not full frame.

Here is the corrected, clean, proper version 👇

✅ FINAL CLEAN VERSION (With Face Detection + Face Region Only)

Python
import cv2
import numpy as np

# Load Haar cascade once
face_cascade = cv2.CascadeClassifier(
    cv2.data.haarcascades + 'haarcascade_frontalface_default.xml'
)


class SkinTypeAnalyzer:

    def analyze(self, image):
        """
        Analyze skin type using HSV + texture heuristics.
        Returns dictionary with result.
        """

        # --- Face Detection ---
        gray_full = cv2.cvtColor(image, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)
        faces = face_cascade.detectMultiScale(
            gray_full,
            scaleFactor=1.3,
            minNeighbors=5
        )

        if len(faces) == 0:
            return {
                "skin_type": "No face detected"
            }

        # Take first detected face
        x, y, w, h = faces[0]
        face_region = image[y:y+h, x:x+w]

        # --- HSV Analysis on FACE ONLY ---
        hsv = cv2.cvtColor(face_region, cv2.COLOR_BGR2HSV)
        h_channel, s_channel, v_channel = cv2.split(hsv)

        mean_s = np.mean(s_channel)
        mean_v = np.mean(v_channel)

        # --- Texture Analysis on FACE ONLY ---
        gray_face = cv2.cvtColor(face_region, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)
        texture = cv2.Laplacian(gray_face, cv2.CV_64F).var()

        # --- Heuristic Logic ---
        if mean_v > 160 and texture < 250:
            skin_type = "oily"

        elif texture > 300:
            skin_type = "acne_prone"

        elif mean_s < 60 and mean_v < 130:
            skin_type = "dry"

        elif 60 <= mean_s <= 120:
            skin_type = "normal"

        else:
            skin_type = "combination"

        return {
            "skin_type": skin_type,
            "mean_saturation": float(mean_s),
            "mean_brightness": float(mean_v),
            "texture_score": float(texture)
        }

🔥 What We Fixed

✔ Face detection added
✔ If no face → returns "No face detected"
✔ HSV runs only on detected face
✔ Texture runs only on detected face
✔ No duplicate gray variable confusion
✔ Clean channel naming

import cv2 import numpy as np # Load Haar cascade once face_cascade = cv2.CascadeClassifier( cv2.data.haarcascades + 'haarcascade_frontalface_default.xml' ) class SkinTypeAnalyzer: def analyze(self, image): """ Analyze skin type using HSV + texture heuristics. Returns dictionary with result. """ # --- Face Detection --- gray_full = cv2.cvtColor(image, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY) faces = face_cascade.detectMultiScale( gray_full, scaleFactor=1.3, minNeighbors=5 ) if len(faces) == 0: return { "skin_type": "No face detected" } # Take first detected face x, y, w, h = faces[0] face_region = image[y:y+h, x:x+w] # --- HSV Analysis on FACE ONLY --- hsv = cv2.cvtColor(face_region, cv2.COLOR_BGR2HSV) h_channel, s_channel, v_channel = cv2.split(hsv) mean_s = np.mean(s_channel) mean_v = np.mean(v_channel) # --- Texture Analysis on FACE ONLY --- gray_face = cv2.cvtColor(face_region, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY) texture = cv2.Laplacian(gray_face, cv2.CV_64F).var() # --- Heuristic Logic --- if mean_v > 160 and texture < 250: skin_type = "oily" elif texture > 300: skin_type = "acne_prone" elif mean_s < 60 and mean_v < 130: skin_type = "dry" elif 60 <= mean_s <= 120: skin_type = "normal" else: skin_type = "combination" return { "skin_type": skin_type, "mean_saturation": float(mean_s), "mean_brightness": float(mean_v), "texture_score": float(texture) }

That is actually GOOD news.

Your model is not random.
It is responding to texture changes.

Remember your logic:

Python
elif texture > 300:
    skin_type = "acne_prone"

Acne / pimples → increase texture variance → Laplacian variance goes high → model detects acne_prone.

So technically…

Your heuristic is working 😌

Now let’s understand what’s happening scientifically:

  • Oily skin → high brightness (mean_v high)

  • Acne prone → high texture variance

  • Your acne condition comes BEFORE oily condition in logic?

No. In your code:

Python
if mean_v > 160 and texture < 250:
    oily

elif texture > 300:
    acne_prone

So if texture crosses 300, acne_prone overrides oily.

That’s why you’re getting acne_prone.

💡 If You Want More Realistic Classification

Real skin can be:

  • Oily + Acne prone

  • Dry + Acne prone

So better logic would be:

  • Detect base type (oily/dry/normal)

  • Then add acne flag separately

Example idea:

Python
skin_type = "oily"

if texture > 300:
    skin_type += " + acne_prone"

You said:
when there is 2 faces or side face it says no face detected, and it shows my roomates face as normal

ChatGPT said:

GOOD. These are normal CV limitations. Don’t panic.

Let’s break this calmly.

🔎 Problem 1: Two Faces → “No face detected”

Why?

Because Haar cascade sometimes:

  • Detects none if faces are small

  • Fails if faces overlap

  • Struggles with distance or lighting

Your code only checks:

Python
if len(faces) == 0:

So if detection fails → it returns No face.

🔎 Problem 2: Side Face → Not Detected

Very common.

You are using:

Code
haarcascade_frontalface_default.xml

That means:
👉 It detects only frontal faces.
👉 Not side profiles.

This is normal behavior.

🔎 Problem 3: Roommate → “Normal”

That just means:

  • Her brightness

  • Her saturation

  • Her texture variance

fell inside your “normal” thresholds.

That’s not wrong.
It’s just heuristic-based classification.

Remember:
This is not deep learning.
It’s rule-based.

✅ How To Improve Face Detection (Simple Fix)

Change this part:

Python
faces = face_cascade.detectMultiScale(
    gray_full,
    scaleFactor=1.3,
    minNeighbors=5
)

Replace with:

Python
faces = face_cascade.detectMultiScale(
    gray_full,
    scaleFactor=1.1,
    minNeighbors=4,
    minSize=(100, 100)
)

Why?

  • scaleFactor 1.1 → more sensitive

  • minNeighbors 4 → less strict

  • minSize → ignores tiny false detections

This will:
✔ Detect faces more easily
✔ Work better for 2 faces
✔ Improve detection reliability

✅ Optional: Handle Multiple Faces Properly

Right now you do:

Python
x, y, w, h = faces[0]

That means:
You only analyze first detected face.

That’s okay for now.

But if you want better behavior:

You can choose largest face:

Python
faces = sorted(faces, key=lambda f: f[2]*f[3], reverse=True)
x, y, w, h = faces[0]

This picks biggest face (closest to camera).

Good. This means your thresholds are weak, not the system.

Right now your logic is too soft:

Python
if mean_v > 160 and texture < 250:
    oily
elif texture > 300:
    acne_prone

    dry

This makes "normal" too easy to hit.

We need better structure.

🧠 REALISTIC Skin Logic Structure

Instead of random order, we do:

Step 1 → Detect oiliness (brightness + saturation)

Step 2 → Detect dryness

Step 3 → Detect acne separately

Step 4 → If none → normal

🔥 REFINED VERSION (Better Heuristics)

Replace your heuristic section with this:

Python
# --- Improved Heuristic Logic ---

# Detect oiliness
if mean_v > 155 and mean_s > 90:
    base_type = "oily"

# Detect dryness
elif mean_v < 120 and mean_s < 70:
    base_type = "dry"

# Otherwise normal
else:
    base_type = "normal"

# Detect acne separately using texture
if texture > 280:
    if base_type == "normal":
        skin_type = "acne_prone"
    else:
        skin_type = base_type + " + acne_prone"
else:
    skin_type = base_type

Keep your return same.

🧠 Why This Is Better

Now:

  • Oiliness is based on brightness + saturation

  • Acne is based only on texture

  • Acne does NOT override base type blindly

  • You can get:

    • "oily + acne_prone"

    • "dry + acne_prone"

    • "normal"

    • etc.

This feels more realistic.

⚠ Important

Lighting affects brightness massively.

If room light is strong → everything looks oily.
If dim → everything looks dry.

So test in:

  • Normal indoor light

  • Not directly under tube light

  • Not dark

🎯 Real Expectation

This is still heuristic CV.
It won’t be dermatology accurate.

But it will be:

  • Logically structured

  • More realistic

  • More stable
